Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Small: Structured-Network Coding: Fundamental Limits via Submodular Function Optimization

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Distributed and cloud storage are emerging technologies that transform the way personal and enterprise data are managed today. This project proposes network coding as a modeling tool to study efficient design and operation of distributed and cloud storage systems. The principal aim of this project is to develop mathematical tools that build upon the submodularity of Shannon entropy to capture the structure of such engineering network coding problems, yielding strong yet easy-to-compute network coding bounds. Two specific focuses of this project are: 1) combinatorial characterization of subset entropy inequalities; and 2) generalized cut-set bounds for broadcast networks.

Our proposed study of network coding represents a significant deviation from the traditional view, where network coding is seen as a collection of pure mathematical problems. This deviation allows us to focus on the appropriate tools from combinatorics and information theory and draw strength from engineering intuitions. Both the theoretical development and the engineering results from this project are expected to impact how the field of network coding evolves over the next few years. The proposed research programs are hand-in-hand with our continuing efforts in training undergraduate and graduate students, broadening the participation of women and African Americans in engineering, and encouraging future scientists through outreach to high-school students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main focus of this project was to use information theory to understand the fundamental limits of signal interactions in data storage and machine learning systems. This represents a significant deviation from the traditional view, where information theory was mainly used to study the fundamental limits of reliable communication over noisy medium. Our main approach was to use combinatorics to capture the specific structure of each problem, and the proposed combinatorial structures have led to tight converse results for several canonical distributed storage problems and an information-theoretic framework for data clustering ("info-clustering"), which is not only general enough to capture complex similarity structures, but is also able to reduce to more practical algorithms under verifiable model assumptions. These results demonstrated that combinatorics can be extremely useful for characterizing the fundamental limits of complex information systems. And we expect such a "combinatorial information-theoretic" approach to continue to play key roles in solving important problems in private information retrieval, distributed computation, data structures, and machine learning. In addition, the established fundamental limits provide important guidelines for designing efficient distributed storage systems, and the algorithms derived from the proposed info-clustering framework add to the existing repertoire that may help to facilitate scientific explorations in bioinformatics and neural science applications.

The aforementioned research programs were accompanied by the PI's continuing effort in curriculum development, involving undergraduate and graduate students in research, and broadening the participation of women and African Americans in engineering. A new course on submodular functions and optimization was offered by the PI at Texas A&M during Fall 2016, and the developed educational materials have been and will be continuously made available at the course website.
